sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Angi Elias has made a fair copy of C's latest graph of the C-major Prelude (Wohltemperirtes Clavier, Book I), which S may use in his seminar; C to write thanking Elias; S comments on changes to C's graph.

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Cube, undated [November/December 1931]

tei:transcription.tei:p: Frl. Elias| Click on Angi Elias. hat über meine Aufforderung für Sie eine Reinschrift der Arbeit gemacht, die ich mit ihr in den Stunden fertiggestellt habe[corr]. The Prelude in C major from the Well-Tempered Clavier, Book 1. Although the present letter is undated, it is clearly a response to C’s letter of October 20, 1931 (OJ 9/34, [29]), and the graph of the Bach prelude that he had recently prepared, not the graph of the same prelude sent to Schenker on January 2, 1930 (OJ 9/34, [20]). For an earlier transcription and translation, and facsimile reproduction, see William Drabkin, “A Lesson in Analysis from Heinrich Schenker: the C Major Prelude from Bach’s Well-Tempered Clavier, Book I,” Music Analysis, 4 (1985), pp. 241-58 (where the letter was misdated). Dieses Stadium ist fast druckfertig, dennoch werde ich die Tafel bei Gelegenheit der Durcharbeitung auch in meinem kleinen Seminarchen The weekly seminar in analysis (comprising Felix Salzer and three students of Hans Weisse (who had left for New York), Trude Kral, Greta Kraus, and Manfred Willfort) in Schenker’s apartment, which ran for three seasons (1931-4), is described briefly in Salzer’s forward to the reprint of the Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln as Five Graphic Music Analyses (New York: Dover, 1969), see pp. 17-21. vielleicht noch “gustiren” u. dies u. jenes (vielleicht!) noch veredeln, verdeutlichen, sodaß das Bild ^auch^ ohne Text “reden” kann. In his letter of October 16, 1931 9OJ 9/34, [28]), C had indicated that a “schriftliche[] Erläuterung” would accompany his graphic analysis of the prelude. The concept of Urlinie-Tafel, in which such commentary is no longer required, is enshrined in the phrase “the picture can speak even without a text.” Das Blatt des Frl. El. dürfen Sie ohne Weiteres {2} schon in den Dienst Ihres Unterrichtes stellen!
Nun eine Bitte: machen Sie ein Schönbild des Blattes, das mir zur Vorlage im Seminar dienen könnte. Vielleicht bleibt Ihre Vorlage die letzte u. geht in Stich oder zum Photographen oder . .

Zuletzt erhält Prof Violin| Click on Moriz Violin. die Vorlage (nebst 10/^12^ von Chop.) The Etude in C minor, Op. 10, No. 12, often known as the “Revolutionary Etude”, is the last work graphed in the Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln. u. wir beginnen die Beratung über die Form der Veröffentlichung u. Verwertung.

An Frl. Elias bitte ich ein Paar Zeilen des Dankes zu richten [cued from lower margin: Frl. Angi Elias, Wien [/] I, Gölsdorfstr. 4]. Vielleicht hat sie Gelegenheit, noch weitere Dienste mit ihren in den Stunden (allerdings nicht ganz druckfertig<del>en</del>) erreichten Vorlagen zu leisten.
{3} Achten Sie genauer auf die Bogen!

Fis des Basses in T.^22^ ist nur wegen es<sup>1</sup> der Oberst. da (besser an sich: fis<sup>b7</sup> als [natural]f<sup>b7</sup>); ist es<sup>1</sup> zu d^1^ fortgegangen, so ist wieder f notwendig geworden, wenn [slur]7 folgen soll. Gemäß dem Gesetz: “man habe den Griff schon in der Hand” (Em. Bach) C. P. E. Bach Versuch über die wahre Art das Clavier zu spielen (Berlin: author, 1753–62). S owned a copy of the Gustav Schilling edition (Berlin: Fr. Stage, 1856) (Musik und Theater, Enthaltend die Bibliothek des Herrn Dr. Heinrich Schenker, Wien (Vienna: Antiquariat Heinrich Hinterberger, n.d.)). [identify passage referred to] gehört denn f in die l. H. Daher ist fis des Basses u. f der Mittelst. kein Querstand: je eigener Grund waltet dort u. hier, die Folge stellt keinen Zusammenhang beider Töne<del>n</del> vor. Endlich: die Sekund d^1^–c^1^ im 6/5 über As läßt als Sekund eine Auskomponierung in der früheren Art nicht zu! Daher u. nur deshalb fingiert Bach dem Terzraum h–d^1^, um etwas ähnliches zu bringen. (Kommt oft bei ihm u. Anderen vor) S is probably thinking of Bach’s Violin Concerto in E, first movement, mm. 23–24, where the interval of a third in the bass is similarly filled in by passing note and the diminution has “a life of its own”; see Das Meisterwerk in der Musik, vol. 1 (1925), p. 120 (Eng. trans., p. 64), Fig. 2. The example is repeated in Der freie Satz (Fig. 119/16a). {4} Den Rest entnehmen Sie leicht dem Bild u. den Korrekturen Ihres Blattes.

Von Prof Violin| Click on Moriz Violin. werden Sie den Inhalt des Briefes von Weisse erfahren. Er ist schon wirklich erhebend. By this time, Hans Weisse had arrived in New York to teach at the David Mannes School of Music. Der Einfachheit halber lege ich alle Briefe u. Beilagen zusammen.
Mit besten Grüßen von uns Beiden

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Cube, undated [November/December 1931]

tei:translation.tei:p: At my request, Miss Elias has made a fair copy of the work, which I completed with her during her lessons. This version is nearly ready for publication; nevertheless I will use the opportunity of revision perhaps still to “savor” the graph in my little seminar group, and to further ennoble and clarify matters here and there (possibly!), so that the picture can “speak” ^even^ without text. You may now, without further ado, place Fräulein Elias’s work {2} in the service of your teaching!

Now, I have a favor to ask of you. Make a fair copy of this page, which I can use as a model in my seminar. Perhaps your model will remain the final version and will be printed or photo-reproduced, or …
In the end, Professor Violin will receive the model (along with Chopin’s Op.10, No. 12), and we shall begin consultation about the form of the publication and how it will be used.

Please send a few words of thanks to Miss Elias [cued from lower margin: Frl. Angi Elias, Wien I, Gölsdorfstrasse 4]. Perhaps she will have the occasion to render yet other services, with the models that she has prepared in her lessons, even if these are not entirely ready for publication.
{3} Pay closer attention to the slurs!

F# appears in the bass in bar ^22^ only because of eb<sup>1</sup> in the upper voice (as support for the flattened seventh: f-sharp is better per se than f-natural). As soon as eb<sup>1</sup> has proceeded to d^1^, the f has once again become important if [slur]7 is to follow. In accordance with C. P. E. Bach’s principle, that “the keys should already be lying beneath the hand,” f belongs in the left hand. For this reason, f# in the bass versus f in the middle voice does not signify a cross relation: each note has its own reason for being there; the succession does not represent any connection between the two notes. Finally: the second d^1^–c^1^ in the 6/5 above Ab, being a second, does not permit an elaboration of the sort that occurred earlier. For this reason, and only this reason, Bach pretends that there is the space of a third between b and d^1^, to produce something similar. (This happens frequently in the music of Bach, and others.) {4} The rest you will understand easily from the graph and from the corrections to your work.
You will learn from Professor Violin the content of Weisse’s letter. It is indeed most encouraging. For sake of simplicity I am putting all letters and additional material together.
With best wishes from the two of us, Yours, [signed:] H. Schenker
